profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-01-02T19:42-0500

repository.corpname: Jewish Historical Society of Greater Hartford

physdesc.extent: Paper format: 7 document boxes and 1 box of photographs

did.abstract: The Holocaust collection consists of personal testimonies, newspaper clippings, pamphlets, and photographs. Most of the material focuses on the experiences of survivors and witnesses who settled in the Greater Hartford area. Some material is related to national and international Holocaust studies and commemorations. The most significant portion of the collection consists of audio and videotaped interviews of local Holocaust survivors.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Many of these interviews are also available in transcript form. See list below or People chart for details. Steven Spielberg, as part of his Survivors of Shoah project, interviewed other local survivors. Those oral histories can be accessed at: http://www.vhf.org/. As of this date, July 6, 2006, last names of interviewees are not given in the online version, but are available on the CD version.

did.unittitle: General/Art and music/Karas, Joza, research on music composed in Terezin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Karas is a Holocaust survivor who is known for his written work, "Music in Terezin 1941-1945". A violinist and instructor of music at the Hartt School, Mr. Karas was born in Poland, raised in Chechoslovakia.
In addition to newspaper articles discussing Mr. Karas' biography and community works, this folder includes a musical program to the Hartford Symphony Orchestra presenting "Brundibar".

scopecontent.p: Newspaper articles featuring biographical information and events related to Mr. Hiram Bingham.

controlaccess.persname: Bingham IV, Hiram "Harry", Attorney, Salem, CT

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspaper articles from the late 1990's relating Jewish responses to Catholic Church and John Paul II position on Shoah.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: File contains commemoration program held by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Council, April 1984, and a booklet on the Holocaust Memorial Museum, its first five years (1993-1998).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Holocaust related newspaper articles published by CT Jewish Ledger.

physdesc.extent: 1943 Telegraphed Bulletin (1943) original, several orignial newspaper clippings, New Republic booklet, and photocopies of newspaper articles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This file contains several newspaper articles related to anti-Nazi protests during the early 1940s, and other community happenings in and around Hartford during the early WWII period. Contents include an original telegraph bulletin related to the liquidation of the Vilna Ghetto (1943) and a booklet from the New Republic entitled, "The Jews of Europe": How to Help Them", (1943).

controlaccess.persname: Cohen, Emma Perlstein, b.December 1, 1904, Hartford, CT
controlaccess.subject: pre-Nazi Germany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: File contains several newspaper articles dating back to 1933 reporting Holocaust resistance and protest. Also, of special significance is a 1933 booklet entitled, "The Boycott is Our Only Weapon Against Nazi Germany", authored by Samuel Untermyer, and a 1946 booklet entitled "Balance Sheet of Extermination", authored by Jacob Lestchinsky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains several newspaper articles and editorials covering the topic of Holocaust denial or repudiation. Many of the articles published by the Jewish Ledger and the Hartford Courant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Folder contains two newspaper articles from the Jewish Ledger, dated 1997, that report about the "Little Boat That Could" -- a sea vessel named the "Gerda III" that rescued Danish Jews to nearby Sweeden in 1943. The article discusses how the ship ferried over 7200 Jews to saftey during the war and was visiting Mystic Seaport in 1998.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This file contains many assorted newspaper articles reporting on performances, movies, television programs, etc. related to the Holocaust. Articles date back to 1983, but many are undated. There also are programs from the Yale Repertory Theatre from teh 2005 season - "Comedy on the Bridge" and "Brundibar". Additionally, the file contains a program from the JCC sponsored performance of "...I never saw another butterfly", with accompanying children's poetry from survivors of the Terezin Concentration camp.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The newspaper articles in this file discuss the ongoing legacy of Anne Frank as it has related to Hartford in the recent past.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

In addition, there is a booklet published by the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany and a published lecture by Saul Touster (1999) entitled "The Treatment of Jewish Survivors of the Holocaust, 1945-1948: Dilemmas of Law, Care, and Bureaucracy", delivered at Brandeis University.

did.unittitle: Survivors/International/Hacker, Bronia, cousin of Bernard L. Bloom

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This document contains a translation of an interview conducted in French on the behalf of the Shoah Project with Bronia Hacker, who is the sole survivor of a once large Jewish family who lived in Poland before WW II.
Questions posed by the interviewer are not included in the translation.

In the course of WW II Bronia lost both her parents, her only sibling, and all her aunts, uncles, and cousins. At the end of the war she was completely alone and found herself in Vienna. Since she is a survivor of the Holocaust, she tells a story that includes a good deal of luck as well as tragedy.

Some of the correspondence relates to involvement in this project by the Jewish Historical Society of Greater Hartford. On particular significance are listings of Holocaust survivors in the state of CT by city and local address, dated 1986.

physdesc.extent: Newspaper clippings and copied biography/press release.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Henry Levy, a resident of West Hartford, Connecticut was born in April 1926, in Salonica, Greece. Mr. Levy fled Salonica for Palestine in March 1942, when the town was under Nazi occupation. He was soon captured near the Turkish border, imprisoned and brutally interrogated in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, sentenced to die as a spy and shuffled from prison to prison, and, finally, deported to the Birkenau concentration camp in the spring of 1943.

In August 1943, Mr. Levy and 3500 other Greek Jews were transported from the camp to Warsaw to remove the debris from its ghetto. They removed the corpses of Jewish resistance fighters, as well as those of the SS officers and others who fought against the resistance. They also built what became the Warsaw concentra¬tion camp, and witnessed such horrors as the degrading conversion of a synagogue into a stable for SS horses. In November 1944, the Warsaw Ghetto was razed and its inhabitants moved to the Dachau concentration camp. More than half perished during the long journey on foot. At the camp, Mr. Levy was assigned to help in the manufacture of concrete blocks and ammunition. He made sure that much of his output was defective. On March 27, 1945, Dachau was evacuated and its inhabitants transported by train, for 33 days, without apparent destination. On May 1, 1945, the train doors opened and the captives were free. The war was over.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspaper articles from the Hartford Courant (09/17/1991) featuring story on West Hartford Holocaust survivor Henry Levy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jewish Ledger article (10/04/1990) featuring story of Eva and Martin Libitzky of Manchester traveling to Poland to visit Holocaust sites.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: West Hartford News article (09/07/1989) featuring a story on the visit of Walter Lindauer to Stuttgart, Germany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Roman Luftglas was born in 1925 in Poland. A Holocaust survivor, Roman later worked in Germany at the American Joint Distribution Committee and showed movies to fellow survivors at DP camps. An American man named Dr. Haber gave Roman the opportunity he had been unable to fulfill: going to America. On a trip to Munich to clean his camera equipment, Mr. Luftglas learned that Dr. Haber had found a sponsor for him, the Jewish Committee of Columbia, SC, to come and live in the United States. Before leaving for the U.S., Roman spent time mastering trade skills such as welding and auto-mechanics in attempts to learn a skill that may be useful when he arrived in the States. Three months later on a Saturday in 1950, Roman arrived by ship to Columbia, South Carolina. Roman began to work immediately and held a series of jobs that required his technical and mechanical skills. After applying for citizenship, Roman was drafted into the United States Army at the age of 25 and was sent to Fort Jackson, South Carolina to begin basic training. Roman was then sent to Louisiana and was trained to be a CW operator which he mastered, though it was very difficult. Part of the 45th Infantry, also named Thunderbird, Roman was shipped out to Japan and two weeks later arrived in Korea to replace the 40th Division that had been wiped out. Roman spent many hours in a watch tower looking over both sides of the war and took action when necessary. The time that Roman spent in the Korean War was well served and he took many steps to insure his security and survival during the war. He used his skills that he already acquired to better serve his fellow soldiers and himself. He cut hair and showed movies in order to stay safe from patrol duty in the mountains of Korea. He was sent back to the United States and released from the Army at age 27, and moved to Hartford, CT where he met his wife, Goldie. Roman opened a camera shop in West Hartford that he has owned for 40 years. Recently, the Holocaust Museum in Washington, D.C. has donated $10,000 in Roman's name for all that he has accomplished. Throughout his experiences he learned how to be an American by interacting with other soldiers and greatly values what he learned in the Army today. Roman learned to do everything to the best of his ability in order to be proud of himself and his accomplishments. He used the skills he had mastered to create a life that he is very proud of.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a biographical sketch and newspaper articles related to Luftglas' camera business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: George Shainfarber was born in Lodz, Poland, where he lived with his parents and younger sister. In 1939, during the German occupation, his family was forced to move to the Lodz Ghetto.

He attended gymnasium (secondary school) there for one year after which he was ordered to work in a factory. In 1944 his family was sent to Auschwitz when the ghetto was liquidated. From Auschwitz, Mr. Shainfarber was sent to the concentration camp Friedland In Germany. After liberation in May, 1945, he was reunited with his father, but his mother and sister had perished. In 1948, he graduated from the ORT Technical School in Germany and immigrated to the United States in 1950. He completed his education and worked in large appliance sales for many years. As of 1999, Mr. Shainfarber is an active member of the Hartford Jewish Historical Society, the Holocaust Commemoration Committee, and lectures about the Holocaust at schools and colleges. He is married, has two married daughters and six grandchildren.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: There is a Jewish widow (refugee from Poland) in West Hartford , 1179 Boulevard Mrs. Ita Sprung, whose story during the Holocaust should be taped by you. She is very emotional, she cries when she tells her story, so don't tape her story in front of an audience.
Her story is very unusual for several reasons (I think) maybe I'm wrong, because she posed as a shiksah, wore a cross on a chain and was harbored by nuns in a convent.

Her first husband was taken from her; her sister was cremated, her parents too, etc. But there is another aspect to her story (the same as the one I heard from a refugee from Austria) which I wonder if it has been documented* Are others aware of this gruesome aspect2 It is the resentment of certain Jews against other Jews. Am I the only one who hears this?

The one from Austria warned me (wishful thinking) that we Jews in America will experience some day what the Jews in Austria, Germany, Czech., Poland et al have all experienced. This resentment was triggered by the fact that she could not get visas for her son, his wife and their son to come to the U.S. I helped her write letters to Congressmen and Senators and others on a Mag Card machine at work. She had to join them in Israel and she didn't want to go there. She loved the U.S. with its Social Security. She was a furrier and was doing very well here financially. But she writes to me from Haifa and has adjusted very nicely in Israel. She said we are too smug*

The one from Poland is very bitter toward us Americans because she said we didnTt heIn buy up land in Palestine before Hitler and that's why the Jews were not able to escape from Poland, Germany, and the other countries in Europe. They had no place to go.

She is also hitter toward the refugees from Germany because she said they look down their noses at the Polish aid Russian Jews because the German Jews consider themselves to be intellectuals and superior to Polish Jews. She spoke to me in Yiddish so it is hard for me to repeat verbatim what she said. It goes something like this: The German Jews said: "Not our Hitler, he wouldn't mistreat us. He is our Feuhrer. We trust him." I think that was true of German Jews in the early 30's. Many industrial Jews contributed to Hitler's cause because they thought they were going against the Communists and they were capitalists. He pulled the wool over their eyes.

She complained that the Jews in the U.S. didn't want to get involved in WWII. I explained that the reason we got in late is because Joseph Kennedy sent false reports to Roosevelt from the Embassy in (5'eat Britain. Joseph had 5 sons and he didn't want them to get killed in the War. He was an isolationist like Lindbergh and he was buddy- buddy with Neville Chamberlain. But Roosevelt did help Great Britain for years before our Congress declared War against Germany. I have a newspaper clipping that explains that and I worked on Lend-Lease in the Treasury in Wash. D.C. 1937 - 1942 so I know that we were helping Great Britain long before we entered WWII. Not many people are aware of this fact. We supplied Great Britain with airplanes long before Sept. 1939 when we overcame the Isolationists in the U.S. and entered WWII.

I wonder if the historians of the Holocaust are aware of the resentment of Jews against Jews. It amazes me. I am shocked by it and can hardly believe it but I heard it with my own ears. They don't have much respect or gratitude toward us American- Jews. I resent that. Call me and tell me what you think of this subject.
Sincerely, *and think it will never happen to us. She was very bitter toward us. Harriette Katz

did.unittitle: Photo Series II: Europe and Holocaust Photographs
Europe and Holocaust/Antepolye, Grodno, 1929 by David Sherry, originals and negatives
did.materialspec: Caution! The negatives in this set are "nitrate negatives", which are highly flammable. If they show signs of deterioration (stickiness or oozing) contact a professional archival conservator immediately. (New England Document Conservation Center, Andover, MA (978)-470-1010.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Collection created by David Sheery was donated by Mrs. Myer Rogoroff, January 1978.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of multiple photographs depicting rural Jewish peasant life in Poland and Russia, c. 1929. Photos are original, w/ negatives.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: SOME GENERAL COMMENTS ON THE THREE SHTETLACH IN GRODNO GEBERNYEH
These pictures are of three towns:Kobrin, Horodetz, and Antipolia. These shtetlach were situated in Polesiyeh Region in the state of Grodno.

KOBRIN Kobrin was the largest of the three. It had a bigger Jewish population, a high school, and institutions of higher Jewish learning. Kobrin also had a movie house. The town had small factories. The Jews mostly made a living as merchants, shoemakers, tailors, carpenters, and teachers of the Torah. HORODETZ

Horodetz was located on the Dnepper-Burgsky Canal. It also had a train station not far from the center of town. Both of these helped bring commerce to the area. Like all the small towns, it had centers of Jewish study. Horodetz produced authors, artists, and musicians such as Jan Peerce who was born there.

ANTIPOLIA Antipolia was bigger than Horodetz and had more Jewish inhabitants. In 1914 a commercial high school was opened as well as a four-year preparatory school before high s school for girls. There was a Talmud Torah and private teachers and rabbis who ran schools to teach the children Hebrew and Jewish history. The schools opened at 8 a.m. and closed at 8 p.m., and learning went on for a l2-hour period. Two Hebrew news- storekeepers, workers, blacksmiths, and other types of workers. Some were merchants that boughts and sold grain; others dealt with lumber. Several Jews rented farms and worked the land since they themselves couldn't own the land; many were dairy farners. These Jews had a better standard of living. Youths who sought higher education came to this shtetl to be instructed.They ate in the middle-class homes and slept on the hard benches in the synagogues. In these three towns were ardent Zionists who worked for their ideals and donated all they could for the cause. On Saturdays the middle-class Jews would gather in a house. They would discuss religion and politics and play chess. The tragedy of today is that these shtetlach are without any Jews. Although they produced well-educated, talented, and devoted Jews for many years before World Var II, the Holocaust erased all signs of Jewish life there.
